body:
This is a similar issue to #312

I think rclone should still log at the level required though so the logs would appear above the progress, eg

```
log line
log line
progress display
```

What I'd probaby do is take the existing stats output and use that as the progress display.

So the display might look like this (with -v) with the logs scrolling up but the display staying constant at the bottom.

```
2018/06/10 15:20:57 INFO  : xerejiw7fa: Copied (new)
2018/06/10 15:20:57 INFO  : ferejej3gux/gimak: Copied (new)
2018/06/10 15:20:57 INFO  : numewis3/bupitoq: Copied (new)
2018/06/10 15:20:57 INFO  : qucad/bogubic: Copied (new)
2018/06/10 15:20:58 INFO  : lofu/beyedub7q: Copied (new)
2018/06/10 15:20:58 INFO  : gapexuc4/bacopey5qey: Copied (new)
2018/06/10 15:20:58 INFO  : rabokoh9pol/galonad: Copied (new)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Transferred:   2.052 kBytes (404 Bytes/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:                 0
Transferred:           44
Elapsed time:        5.1s
Transferring:
 *                                   misex/furaz: 100% /67, 0/s, 0s
 *                               neyagij5da/bata: 100% /76, 0/s, 0s
 *                            ferejej3gux/hehiwu: 100% /62, 0/s, 0s
 *                            numewis3/cewiqib3s: 100% /11, 0/s, 0s
```

What do you think of something like that?

What's particularly important to me is to see the amount of data that will be transferred in total, and the estimated time it will take to do that. I am not so much interested in statistics for individual files, because in my use-case, most files are only a few megabyte in size. Thus stats displays information that I am not interested in, while omitting what is.

rclone doesn't know the amount of stuff that needs to be transferred in total without scanning the source and destination first.  Normally rclone does this in parallel with the transfers to speed things up and save memory.

So what rclone could do is the equivalent of do a `--dry-run` sync writing each file that needs transferring to a file, then do a sync with `--files-from` just to transfer those files.

I made a sort of proof of concept of how the stats and the logging would combine.  So the lines which start `Line` are the stats and the others are scrolling log lines.

[![asciicast](https://asciinema.org/a/189216.png)](https://asciinema.org/a/189216)

What do you think?

issue.title: Update stats in place

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
<!--

Hi!

We understand you are having a problem with rclone or have an idea for an improvement - we want to help you with that!

If you've just got a question or aren't sure if you've found a bug then please use the rclone forum

    https://forum.rclone.org/

instead of filing an issue.  We'll reply quickly and it won't increase our massive issue backlog.

If you think you might have found a bug, please can you try to replicate it with the latest beta?

    https://beta.rclone.org/
    
If you can still replicate it with the latest beta, then please fill in the info below which makes our lives much easier.  A log with -vv will make our day :-)

If you have an idea for an improvement, then please search the old issues first and if you don't find your idea, make a new issue.

Thanks

The Rclone Developers

-->

#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?
None yet

#### What is your rclone version (eg output from `rclone -V`)
```
rclone v1.42
- os/arch: linux/amd64
- go version: go1.10.1
```

#### Which OS you are using and how many bits (eg Windows 7, 64 bit)
Ubuntu 18.04, 64 bit

####  Which cloud storage system are you using? (eg Google Drive)
Google Drive

#### The command you were trying to run (eg `rclone copy /tmp remote:tmp`)
`rclone sync /data/ googledrive --stats=1s -v`



My thought was that instead of my terminal scrolling with every update, it would be nice if it could update stats output in place, or even 'live'.

issue.title: Static stats block with real time updating

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
@ncw Nick, new issue per your request. A static stat block, like the current one, except it's persistent and only the information changes. I'll add my details later when I'm not on mobile, but just wanted to get the issue made for you.

So here's the low-down on the idea from the other issue:

The current stats block....

Transferred: 42.317 MBytes (119.671 kBytes/s)
Errors: 4
Checks: 28252
Transferred: 296
Elapsed time: 6m2s
Transferring:

var/lib/dpkg/info/libssh-4:armhf.list: 100% done, 522 Bytes/s, ETA: 0s
var/lib/dpkg/info/libssh-4:armhf.postrm: 100% done, 132 Bytes/s, ETA: 0s
var/lib/dpkg/info/libssh-4:armhf.md5sums: 100% done, 425 Bytes/s, ETA: 0s
var/lib/dpkg/info/libssh-4:armhf.postinst: 0% done, 0 Bytes/s, ETA: -
Last Error: List last error here.

I say print out this format as a static block if someone uses -stats, then update the stats in place (like --info=progress2 in rync). Adding the last error that was received at the bottom. Write off all errors to a file, then list them once the transfer is done.

Then once the transfer is done, the last block of stats and the errors are written off to output for peoples logs that use them.

This way you can get an update on what's going on at a glance, but you don't have a scrolling wall of text both onscreen and in your logs.

issue.title: See downloads/transfers
issue.body: The ability to see what's downloading and time left / transfer speed?

body: @ncw How's this going? Last result looks very good!
I've been on vacation and conferences but will get back to it shortly!

issue.title: Make stats print to stdout (feature request)

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?
stats print to stderr along with all other logging, but stats don't really make much sense in a log except for maybe an overall summary at the very end.  A periodic stats message is meant to show the user what is going on at that moment (serving as both a general summary and basic progress indicator).  Especially when logging to a file, having a multitude of stats messages interspersed with the actual logs makes for messy log IMO.  Of course you can disable stats entirely to have a cleaner log file, but then you lose any progress indicator entirely.  I would argue that stats should only display on stdout, and there should be a separate option if someone wants a summary of the finished operation printed to stderr.

I know there are currently changes being made to how stats are formatted and operate, but unless I missed something I haven't seen anyone talking recently about stats in the context of stdout/stderr.

Another more general related concept that might be worthwhile would be to have separate log level contexts for transports (one for the console, and another for files).  That would give a lot of flexibility for different scenarios.

I'd love to be able to submit a PR at some point, but I'm not familiar with Go at the moment, so it might be a steep learning curve.

issue.title: Add progress display (stats) for the whole operation

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
## What happens now:

By default, rclone shows total bytes transferred and progress for each transfer thread (each file being transferred). For example `sync local remote:location` shows transferred bytes + 4 lines for 4 threads uploading 4 individual files to the remote backend.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/270528/13523491/0ec89132-e1f6-11e5-8471-1b4e157ec753.png)
## What should happen:

Rclone should display the total progress (and ETA) of the requested operation, i.e. a `sync` operation, which is effectively:

> progress = transfered_files / total_files \* 100%

The current progress display is not very useful, unless someone `syncs` a single file or manually checks the source size and compares against `Transferred`.

IMO The current per-thread progress status should live within `--verbose` progress display for diagnosing stuff like backend rate-limits or transfer limits. By default, rclone should display **total** progress of operation and **total throughput** of all threads - total download/upload speed maintained.

Maybe something inspired by curl progress? 
![](http://i.stack.imgur.com/m7O1i.png)

Or like wget ?
![](http://www.thelinuxterminal.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/wget-download-1140x344_c.png)
![](http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-DlhB25swqEs/UZe0CPLAv6I/AAAAAAAAAIc/Ig5nSOpv2fw/s1600/Progress+Label.png)

issue.title: Proposal for revising stats display.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
Proposal for issue #379

Currently the revised output looks like this:

```
2016/03/12 13:52:25
Checked:           192593 of 46673217 bytes (0.41%) in 5 of 1172 files
Transferred:       176799 of 186888 bytes (3.22 kB/s) in 41 of 50 queued files
Elapsed time:       53.6s
```
## Things to fix before merge
- [ ] `func Check(fdst, fsrc Fs)` should also update stats.
- [ ] If a file exist on src, that doesn't on dst, it is not added to "checked". That breaks this method of displaying stats.
- [ ] Add file deletion information.
- [ ] Tests.

Of course we should also agree that this is the right direction.

body:
OK here is the next iteration. This has whole operation stats and supports --stats-one-line along with --progress.  I tried to make `--progress --one-line` look like rsync's `progress2` equivalent.

https://beta.rclone.org/branch/v1.42-126-g0475830a-fix-2347-progress/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

I haven't implemented @ewwink suggestion about switching the order of the transferring files and the transfer stats yet.

That one didn't build, try this one...

https://beta.rclone.org/branch/v1.42-128-gebf185ec-fix-2347-progress/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

I have merged that in

https://beta.rclone.org/v1.42-131-g1cccfa73/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

which will be in [the latest beta](https://beta.rclone.org) and v1.34

I expect that it will get  tweaked as time goes by!
